item.title: A Reproduction of 'Do Female Officers Police Differently? Evidence from Traffic Stops' (American Journal of Political Science, 2021)
item.description: Abstract We reproduce Shoub, Kelsey, Katelyn E. Stauffer, and Miyeon Song ( May 2021). “Do Female Officers Police Differently? Evidence from Traffic Stops,” with alternative specifications and interpretation of the results. While our reproduction confirms that female police officers are less likely to search drivers than male officers and female officers are more likely to find contraband upon a search, we re-evaluate the authors’ claims on the equality of effectiveness between male and female officers and find that female officers in the dataset confiscated less contraband than male officers.

item.title: The Differential Impact of the Hong Kong National Security Law on Political Sensitivity Bias in Local Opinion Polls
item.description: Abstract Political sensitivity bias refers to the deviation of observed poll results from the genuine public opinion due to perceived government pressure on respondents. This bias can mislead analysts and politicians into making inaccurate assessments of political climates. Hong Kong, having experienced a rapid reduction in political freedoms under the Hong Kong National Security Law (HKNSL), provides a unique case for studying political sensitivity bias where the impacts of other transitory factors can be isolated.
